scenario:
U.S. stock futures declined on Wednesday following a muted day of trading on Tuesday. Futures of major benchmark indices were lower in premarket. The Donald Trump administration levied a 245% tariff on China late Tuesday. U.S. export restrictions were also announced, halting the shipments of Nvidia Corp.'s H20 graphics processing units to China.

The 10-year Treasury bond yielded 4.31% and the two-year bond was at 3.81%. The CME Group's FedWatch tool's projections show markets pricing a 79.9% likelihood of the Federal Reserve keeping the current interest rates unchanged in its May meeting.

Futures Change: Dow Jones -0.07%, S&P 500 -0.44%, Nasdaq 100 -1.08%, Russell 2000 -0.35%. The SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) and Invesco QQQ Trust ETF (QQQ) fell in premarket on Wednesday.

Cues From Last Session: Consumer discretionary, health care, and consumer staples sectors saw the biggest declines, while information technology and real estate stocks closed higher. Citigroup Inc. and Bank of America Corp. reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings.

Index Performance: Nasdaq Composite -0.049%, S&P 500 -0.17%, Dow Jones -0.38%, Russell 2000 0.11%. According to Mona Mahajan, stock valuations are no longer stretched, and the upside is that valuations are now looking more compelling.

Analysts' Insights: Mona Mahajan noted that all major indexes were trading at or below their 10-year historical forward price-to-earnings multiples, potentially setting the stage for improved long-term returns. Jason Goepfert noted a historical pattern where the VIX fear index drops from above 50 to the 30 level, the S&P 500 has historically achieved 100% positive gains by year-end.

Upcoming Economic Data: March's U.S. retail sales, industrial production and capacity utilization data for March, business inventories for February, and the home builder confidence index for April will be announced.

Stocks In Focus: Abbott Laboratories rose 0.74% in premarket, Travelers Companies Inc. was up 0.076%, and Progressive Corp. fell 0.01%.
